tagDescription: to D.Cameron. Letter received.Advances already made to Indians; will follow his instructions not to give further credit.
to Duncan Cameron.(No.37.) Letter received.Measures to be taken by North West Company in case of attack.
Copies of statements and declarations of James Grant and William Morrison at Fort William the 5 and 8 October,1816.Taken by John Pritchard to Mr.Seton,3 January,1820.
Fragments of G.Keith's Journal.
to Duncan Cameron. (No.66.) Reports his arrival.Mentions Clarke's exploits in Athabasca.
to James Grant. Report of his journey from Montreal.Understands Lord Selkirk intends to drive the North West Company out of the country.
Men's balances, 1815. ( parcel No.8. ) Containing names of Brules among the other engaged men's names.
Red River Settlement.Provisions received by the brigades at La Chine.
Form of payment orders for Chief Factor.
Allan McDonell's statement relating to Red River affairs. Had no connection with action there.
to Lord Selkirk. Declaration ragarding the surrender of Miles McDonell to the North West Company.
Sundries furnished to Daniel McKenzie and other North West Company people from Red River Stores,1816-17.
to Alex.McDonell.(No.67.) Congratulates him on his success in Red  River. Understands McLeod is building a new government on the ruins of the old one.
to J.Halkett.Memorandum to J.Halkett regarding the Sketch of the Fur Trade.
Declaration on the subject of the attack on Red River.
Denies charges brought against him. Declaration as to affairs at Red River.
(French Copy.) Examination regarding his complicity in the Red River massacre on 19 June.
Extracts from Liancourts Travels.Voyage dans les Etats-Unis d'Amerique fait en 1795,1796 et 1797,par La-Rochefoucauld Liancourt.compte Andriani on the Fur Trade in the interior of America in 1791.
Red River balances,1815, containing names of Bois Brules servants to the North West Company.(parcel No.8.)
Journal for Lac la Pluie Department.
to J.Siveright.Letters received.Regrets lack of provisions but cannot assist.
Inventory of Merchandise delivered to Mr.Chastellain on account of Lord Selkirk,by William Dease of the North West Company.
Declaration on the affair at Red River.Is under bail to appear before the Court in Montreal in September.
to Duncan Cameron (No.21.) Favourable report of local affairs. Is in need of trinkets for gifts for the Indians.
to Dougal Cameron. On the scarcity of supplies.
to Archibald McGillivray. Informing him of the destruction of the Red River Settlement by the North West Company.Has made his will in favour of his wife and son.

to the Agents and Proprietors of the North West Company.(No.75.) Reports transactions in Red River district. Colin Robertson returned with settlers and a strong establishment has been formed. Lack of tobacco and beads felt in trade with the Indians.Freeman all in employ of Hudson's Company.

to Messrs.McTavish,McGillivray & Co. ( Copy. ) Account of proceedings connected with the Hudson's Bay Company. Has purchased stock in the Company.Mr.Inglis and Mr.Ellice purchased sufficient stock to make them to attend the meeting of the Hudson's Bay Company.Instructions for strengthening who posts with men and extra supplies to oppose the Hudson's Bay Company in every way.Forwards catalogue of the Hudson's Bay Company beaver sale.
to Duncan Cameron. (No.29.) Replies to his letter of complaints. Failure of twist tobacco for the Indians a serious matter.
Journal at Isle aux Campements.
Indian Manifesto at Fort William. Sketch of a speech be put into the mouth of an Indian by the North West Company to spread falsehoods against the Hudson's Bay Company.
John McDonald's statement as to affairs at Red River.Never interfered with the settlers.
to Duncan Cameron. Advising him to oppose the Hudson's Bay Company. The Isaac Todd has arrived in China where the furs sold well.
Journal of all the transactions during the summer of 1806. Norman McLeod and John Clarke left for Kaministiguia. Indians bring in furs.
Lists of men.
to John McLaughlin. Gives an unfavourable report of business; mismanagement and rival trade the cause.

to J.Siveright.Informs him of the loss by drowning of Alex.Henry and Donald McTavish off Fort Goerge, on the Pacific Coast,20 May,1814. Mr.Bethune sailed for Canton,China,with all the Columbia furs. The schooner Columbia has gone on a coasting trade towards the Russian settlements.Reports on affairs at Fort Cumberland.
Inventory of Red River property taken by the Halfbreeds and Indians,June 20.Delivered by John Stilt.
to ----.(No.7.) Referring to an account against the North West Company.
Journal, of general transactions and daily occurences at Dunvegan.
to Messrs. Grant,Morrison and Roussin. Instructions. to assemble the Indians and lead them to Red River. No letters nor couriers for the Hudson's Bay Company to be allowed to pass.
Song of the Bois Brules,by Pierre Falcon. ( No.20.Copy. ) Written about the fight of 19 June,1816.

to Duncan Cameron. (No.68.) Indians realize their own traps have reduced the beavers to such an extent few are left. Refers to Harrison's new house at Cumberland House.Refers to loss of Alex.Henry and Donald McTavish by drowing in the Columbia district.
Journal of the daily occurences at Dunvegan,beginning the 18 April.Found by Lord Selkirk at Fort William in August,1816, in a room which had been recently occupied by A.N.McLeod.
Form of Recognizance to be taken from the witnesses to appear in Montreal.
(French.) Engagement to serve the North West Company at Fond de Lac.
Tariff prices of goods sold to the men engaged in service of the North West Company at Fort William.
Journal from June to August.Entry dates mixed.
Indian Chief to Governor Semple. Sketch of a speech.
Canton Sales.
to William McGillivray.(No.44.) Report on local affairs.Remarks on John Clarke's activities. Suggests an augmentayion of salary to keep several of the clerks in the country. Shortage of provisions.
to Dugald Cameron. General report of affairs. John Stewart fully equipped at New Caledonia. Goes to Peace River to visit McGillivray. Iroquois and Freemen who supplied this post have been dispersed.

to Archibald McLellan. Messrs. McBean,McIntosh and Grant appointed Partners in the North West Company. Messrs. John McDonald,Haldane and Leith declared their intention of retiring;also Messrs. McGillis and Campbell going down in rotation.John McGillivray to leave Athabasca as Mr.McLeod goes in.
to Duncan McLeod.)No.33.) Advantage to North West Company from Hudson's Bay Company.Remarks on Clarke's expedition.

toDuncan Cameron. Long letter on general matters connected with the Hudson's Bay Company. Informs him that his letter to Mr. Sayer has been given to Mr.Robertson and sent on to England;blames him for writing and referring to Lord Selkirk as he did.
to Duncan Cameron.(No.11.) Reports his arrival and condition of the Post. Opposition by Hudson's Bay Company.Provisions scarce.
to Duncan Cameron. Favourable report. Hudson's Bay Company affairs. Sir William Shaw is collecting all the Halfbreeds together.Mentions loss of his daughter Peggy.
to Charles Gaultain. (French.) Instructing him to take charge of the North West Company's trade post on the Montreal River.
to J.D.Cameron.Refers to preparations for an apprehended invasion by the Hudson's Bay Company.
No. 1. Inventory of Goods,etc. at Fort William as sold by Daniel McKenzie to Lord Selkirk.
Fragment of a Journal kept by R.Henry. (See 26 January.)
to Hugh McGillis. Refers to the fate of Clarke's expedition. Cameron,Seraphin and Hess taken prisoners at Red River by the colonists.Prospects for the season poor.
Declaration regarding the massacre at Red River.

Statement regarding McLeod's warrant to arrest Lagimodiere. Instructed to raise the Indians against the Red River Settlement; refused.Told to join the South West Company and receive instructions from John Jacob Astor of New York.
Lord Selkirk's manuscript. Sketch of the Fur Trade.
Form of Supoena.
to Messrs. Siveright and Lamar. Further remarks on the opposition of the Hudson's Bay Company.
Journal, continued.
Journal at Dunvegan.
Draft for payment of Â£4 by the North West Company.

The porposed venture to the Pacific to promote the fur trade. David Thompson's expedition to the Columbia River. David McTavish ready to proceed to the Columbia district.Beaver trade. Rate of exchange against the country.
Fragments of Journal by E.Smith, Hay River Establishment.
to Kenneth McKenzie. Remarking on the mismanagement of the North West Company.Arrived at Alexandria on 29 ultimo.
to J.D.Cameron. Regarding Cameron's arrangements with the North West Company; gives him advice.
Commission as Major in the corps of Canadian Voyageur Militia,in the Indian an conquered countries,2 October,1812.
to J.D.Cameron. Reports on state of country.Lack of provisions.Indians in straving condition. Keep up strong opposition to the Hudson's Bay Company.
to Lord Bathurst. Forwards copy of an official communication to his brother regarding Lord Selkirk's settlers on the Red River. Enclosure:-
Form of Summons to bring witnesses before Justice, and affidavit of Lower Canada.
Sundries supplied on account of Lord Selkirk's guard of 7 men of the 37th Regiment.
to J.Bourke. Orders sent to Rnsign Seraphin to change his to position so as to give free attendance to the unfortunate.
to J.D.Cameron. Reports on arrival of the English and difficulty of trading.A number of Highlanders died on the passage out from some disease.Lack of provisions bad for trade.
to Agents of the North West Company (No.84.) Report on trade and state of affairs.
(Parcel No.12.) Receipt for one year's wages.
to J.W.Dease. Regarding North West Company reverses; want of powder. Confident Lord Selkirk will be driven out ultimately.The Governor's Proclamation.
Red River Settlement Day Book kept at Fort William. No.2.
Invoice of sundries for the floating expedition.
to Daniel McKenzie.Fears there will be trouble at Red River in the spring.
to Arch.McLellan. Refers to the desertion of Jean B. Cambeaux and Francois Boucheris and their theft of Company supplies? Consequent lack of provisions.
to Lord Selkirk. Declaration as to occurences at Red River. Surrender of Miles McDonell to the North West Company.
to Duncan Cameron. (No.51.) Replying to complaints made in his private letter of 12 November.
to Arch. McLellan. Referring to movements of Company people; shortage of men tp fill the posts. Warrant issued against Alex.McDonell.Gives him the amount of his account with the Company.
to J.D.Cameron. Letter received Informs him of his promotion to partner will take place in two years terms.
to Lord Selkirk.(Copy.) Statement regarding the letters taken from Lagimodiere.

to Miles McDonell. Account of events in war of 1812-14.General Brock.Declaration of war on 17 June,1812. Fight at Ogdensburgh. Public buildings burnt by the Yankees.Barracks and storehouse at Gibraltar Point burnt.Stoney Creek. Crysler's farm affair on 11 November. Town of Niagara destroyed by fire.Personal affairs.High prices of food.
to Dougal Cameron. Advising him to resist and defy the aggressions of the Hudson's Bay Company.
Form of Mandamus or order to send to gaol a person charged with felony.
(French copy.) Examination regarding his complicity in the Red River Massacre of 19 June,1816.
Draft in his favour for sundries de livered at Red River,signed by C.Campbell.

to W.McGillivray. Informing him of Lord Selkirk's schemes. Miles McDonell expected at Red River in the autumn in charge of the fifty families going to the Settlement. William McGillivray to the North West Company Wintering Partners. Regarding the South West Fur Company.
to Dougal Cameron. (No.1) Regarding the Hudson's Bay Company opposition and trade.
Declaration regarding the massacre at Red River,19 June.
The Red River and Colonial Register. This Book produced by Alexander Johnson Williamson and referred to in his affidavit made before J.M.Mondelet,J.P.
to Duncan Ca meron. Has taken inventory of everything.General report of affairs.
Note by John Pritchard declaring the above letter is in the handwriting of the late Kenneth McKenzie and is endorsed by Hon.William McKenzie.
to Duncan Cameron. Sends two boats with supplies to Bas de la Riviere.Archibald McDonald acting Governor for the Colony.
to Duncan Cameron (No.58.) Referring to an intended expedition to the Mandan villages no doubt an effort to raise some tribes agai nst the colony and the Hudson's Bay Company.
to J.D.Cameron. Personal matters.
Declaration regarding his arrest made before Lord Selkirk.
Journal at Isle aux Campements (sic.)
Statement regarding A.N.McLeod's warrant for the arrest of J.B.Lagimodiere; references to a packet of letters taken from him.
to Miles McDonell. Personal matters.
to Miles McDonell. Reply to his letter. Is not afraid of his threats.
to Cuthbert Grant and the Brules(D.p.13.) Ordering them to dispurse.
Red River Settlement. Charge 1816-17.Sundries received from Alex.Wood,York,U.C.
to William McGillivray. Regarding the North West Company's petition to the King.Personal affairs.
Declaration on the subject of the attack at Red River; had no part in it.
Declaration on the affair at Red River.(French Copy.) Examined by Miles McDonell regarding the Red River troubles.
Journal of Archibald McGillivray,Clerk.
Part of Journal. Copy of letter to Mr. Stuart on Company affairs.

to Selkirk. Informs him that John Pritchard is at the Fort but not as a prisoner.McPherson discharged. Pambrun and Nolin also at the Fort,but not prisoners.John Bourke and Michael Hayden on their way to Montreal asprisoners,both charged upon oath with felony.
Military Order for the escort assigned to Lord Selkirk.
Recapitulation of goods,as above.
Bill of Lading for 8 canoes for Red River.
to Duncan and Dougald Cameron.(No.55.) Congratulates them on success of affairs. Troubles with Hudson's Bay Company continue.
Form of the examination of a person accused of a crime and brought before a Magistrate.
Journal for Riviere des Lairds-a branch of the McKenzie River.
Joseph Defaut's engagement to serve for one year as foreman at Red River.
to Archibald McLellan. Advises him to keep the Halfbreeds together: consequences would be serious should they scatter.

to the North West Company Partners. Regarding plans for opposing Lord Selkirk's colony;insist that he must be driven to abandon it.Has sent communications to the Inverness newspapers and intends to continue them in order to discourage Highlanders from emigrating by every means in his power.
to Duncan Cameron. (No.57.) Regarding his being taken prisoner with others by the Hudson's Bay Company.
Fragment of a Journal by Wentzel at Grand River.
Journal of Archibald McLellan at Lac la Pluie,and of Alex.Henry,Lac d'Ours and Fort Vermillion.
to Messrs. Gillis & Stewart. Rep ort of local affairs.North West Company and Hudson's Bay Company matters.Alarming dearth of animals.
Fragment of a Journal from an outpost pf Fort Dunvegan.
Order for Upper and Lower Red River.
